- Elastic body with crack

## Crack tip singularity

#### Stress field [@williams_stress_1957]

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=20%}
![](figures/crack_tip_illustration.svg){fig-align="center" width=50%}
:::

:::{.column width=80%}
$$
\sigma_{ij}(r, \theta) =
	\frac{\outcol{K_I}}{\sqrt{2\pi r}} f_{ij}^{I}(\theta) +
	\frac{\outcol{K_{II}}}{\sqrt{2\pi r}} f_{ij}^{II}(\theta) +
	\frac{\outcol{K_{III}}}{\sqrt{2\pi r}} f_{ij}^{III}(\theta) + \mathcal{O}(1),
	\quad
	\color{gray}{\sigma_{ij}(r, \theta) \underset{r \to 0}{\to} \infty.}
$$

:::{style="text-align:center"}
There is a stress singularity at crack tip.
:::
:::
::::


::::{.columns}

:::{.column width=40%}
<br>
<br>
<br>

#### Stress Intensity Factors (SIFs)

Denoted $K_m$, they :

- represent the **crack tip sollicitation**,
- depend on **geometry** and **load**.
:::

:::{.column width=60%}
![Source: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fracture_mechanics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fracture_mechanics).](figures/fracture_modes.svg)
:::
::::

:::{.notes}
- Stress field is singular at crack tip
- Stress Intensity Factor quantify the amplitude of the sollicitation
- Depends on the geometry and load (and $\nu$)
:::

## Designing structures with cracks

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=60%}
#### Crack propagation criteria

Propagation criteria rely on the SIFs $K_m$, *e.g.*, 

$\quad \displaystyle \outcol{K_I} \leq K_{Ic}$, or <br><br>
$\quad \displaystyle G = \frac{\outcol{K_{I}}^2 + \outcol{K_{II}}^2}{E'} + \frac{\outcol{K_{III}}^2}{2 \mu} \leq G_c$.

#### How to determine the SIFs ?
Different methods are employed : 

- analytical [(mostly for simple case, or (semi-)infinite domains)]{.muted},
- numerical [(*e.g.*, FEM simulations)]{.muted},
- experimental [(*e.g.*, photo-elasticity, DIC.)]{.muted}.

#### $\to$ Known solutions have been compiled in handbooks!
:::

:::{.column width=40%}
#### Fracture mechanic design handbooks <br> [@tada_stress_2000]

![](figures/tada_et_al_2000_handbook_cover.jpg){fig-align="center" width=70%}

:::
::::

:::{.notes}
- SIFs are employed in crack propagation criteria
- Mean of determination
- Solution for standart and common configurations are compiled in handbooks
:::

## Example [@tada_stress_2000]

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=45%}
![](figures/tada_et_al_2000_round_ct_specimen_illustration.png){fig-align="center" width=100%}
:::
:::{.column width=55%}

#### Methodology in handbook

1. Dimensional analysis
$$
K_I = \bar{\sigma} \sqrt{W} \outcol{\hat{K}_I}(\parcol{A}),
\quad
\bar{\sigma} = \frac{P}{W B},
\quad
A = \frac{a}{W}.
$$
2. Data gathering [(not if analytical method)]{.muted}
   - Observations : $(\parcol{A}, \outcol{\hat{K}_I})$
   - Experimental/Numerical methods
3. Fit polynomial solution to data
$$
\small
\outcol{\hat{K}_I}(\parcol{A})
=
\frac{(2+A)(0.76 + 4.8A - 11.58A^4 + 11.43 A^3 - 4.08 A^4)}{(1-A)^{3/2}}
$$

#### Limitations

Dense polynomials, limited to few parameters, etc.

:::
::::


# Sparse regression {visibility="hidden"}

## Finding a sparse analytical model

Colors: $\parcol{\text{Inputs (parameters)} \pp},  \color{blue}{\text{Coefficients } \cc},  \outcol{\text{Outputs } \Kp{m}}$.

#### Objective
For a structure and load parameterized by $\pp = [\pc{1}, \pc{2}, ..., \pc{N}]^{T}$, find the relationship $\Kp{m}(\pp)$.


#### Tool : LASSO regression [@tibshirani_regression_1996]
We look for a polynomial approximation of degree $d$ [(hyperparameter)]{.muted}
$$
\Kp{m}(\pp) \approx \tildeKp{m}{\cc}(\pp) = \sum_{i_1} \sum_{i_2} \cdot\cdot\cdot \sum_{i_N} \ccc{i_1, i_2, ..., i_n} \pc{1}^{i_1} \pc{2}^{i_2} ...  \pc{N}^{i_P}.
$$
For $\Nobs$ observations ($\pp$, $\Kp{m}$), the optimal coefficients $\ccopt$ minimizes
$$
\ccopt
=
\arg\min_{\cc}
\frac{1}{2 \Nobs} \sum_{\boldsymbol{p}} \left(\tildeKp{m}{\cc}(\pp) - \Kp{m}(\pp) \right)^2
+
\beta
\color{blue}{\| \cc \|_1}
, \quad
\color{gray}{\| \boldsymbol{c} \|_1 = \sum_n | c_n |,}
$$
where $\beta$ is a hyperparameter. The L1-norm of the coefficients $\cc$ drives irrelevant coefficients to zero.

#### Adding non-polynomial terms to model

Replace $\pp$ with $\mathbf{s} = [\pc{1}, \pc{2}, ..., \pc{N}, f(\pc{i})]$.

:::{.notes}
- Our goal is to lift those limitations.
- etc.
:::

# Applications {visibility="hidden"}

## Ex. 1 : CT specimen - Setup & Data
::::{.columns}

:::{.column width=50%}

<br>

#### Parameters and Observations


:::{.r-stack}

![](figures/ct_specimen_observations.svg){width=100%}

![](figures/ct_specimen.svg){.absolute top=250 left=150 width=20%}

:::

:::

:::{.column width=50%}

#### 1. Dimensional analysis

$$
K_I = \sigma \sqrt{a} \outcol{\hat{K}_I}\left(\parcol{\frac{a}{b}}\right)
, \quad
\sigma = \frac{P}{b}.
$$

#### 2. Data gathering 

- Observations [(elastic simulations)]{.muted} : $\left(\parcol{\frac{a}{b}}, \outcol{\hat{K}_I}\right)$

#### 3. Sparse regression

$$\pp = \left[ \parcol{\frac{a}{b}}, \exp\left(\parcol{a/b}\right), \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\parcol{a/b}}} \right]$$

- Hyperparameters :
	- Vary $\beta$ $\to$ find good accuracy-simplicity tradeoff
	- $d=2$, increase until satisfied.

:::

::::

## Ex. 2 : Rotating structure - Physics

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=41%}

#### Illustration

![](figures/rotating_structure_problem.svg){fig-align="center" width=100%}

#### 7-parameter problem

- Geometry: $\color{green}{W, L, a, L_c}$.
- 3D volumic loads:
  - **centrifugal** : $\boldsymbol{f}_\Omega(r, \theta) \propto \color{green}{\Omega}$
    - along $\boldsymbol{e}_r$ and $\boldsymbol{e}_\theta$,
  - **Euler** : $\boldsymbol{f}_\dot{\Omega}(r, \theta) \propto \color{green}{\dot{\Omega}}$
    - along $\boldsymbol{e}_2 = \cos(\alphap) \boldsymbol{e}_\theta - \sin(\alphap) \boldsymbol{e}_z$.
:::

:::{.column width=58% .fragment}
#### Dimensional analysis [(towards a 3-parameter problem)]{.muted}
The superposition principle ($K_m = K_{m}^{\Omega} + K_{m}^{\dot{\Omega}}$) and the Buckingham $\Pi$ theorem give [($\frac{L}{W}$ is fixed)]{.muted}

- centrifugal load
  - $K_{I}^{\Omega}   = \rho \color{green}{\Omega}^2 \color{green}{W}^{5/2} \color{red}{\hat{K}_{I}^{\Omega}}\left(\color{green}{\frac{a}{W}}, \color{green}{\frac{L_c}{L}}, \color{gray}{\frac{L}{W}}\right)$
  - $K_{II}^{\Omega}  = \rho \color{green}{\Omega}^2 \color{green}{W}^{5/2} \color{red}{\hat{K}_{II}^{\Omega}}\left(\color{green}{\frac{a}{W}}, \color{green}{\frac{L_c}{L}}, \color{gray}{\frac{L}{W}}\right)$
  - $K_{III}^{\Omega} = 0$,
- Euler load
  - $K_{I}^{\dot{\Omega}}   = \rho \color{green}{\dot{\Omega}} \color{green}{W}^{5/2} \cos(\color{green}{\alpha}) \color{red}{\hat{K}_{I}^{\dot{\Omega}}}\left(\color{green}{\frac{a}{W}}, \color{green}{\frac{L_c}{L}}, \color{gray}{\frac{L}{W}}\right)$
  - $K_{II}^{\dot{\Omega}}  = \rho \color{green}{\dot{\Omega}} \color{green}{W}^{5/2} \cos(\color{green}{\alpha}) \color{red}{\hat{K}_{II}^{\dot{\Omega}}}\left(\color{green}{\frac{a}{W}}, \color{green}{\frac{L_c}{L}}, \color{gray}{\frac{L}{W}}\right)$
  - $K_{III}^{\dot{\Omega}} = \rho \color{green}{\dot{\Omega}} \color{green}{W}^{5/2} \sin(\color{green}{\alpha}) \color{red}{\hat{K}_{III}^{\dot{\Omega}}}\left(\color{green}{\frac{a}{W}}, \color{green}{\frac{L_c}{L}}, \color{gray}{\frac{L}{W}}\right)$.

:::
::::

| $\displaystyle \hat{K}_{I}^{\Omega} = \exp\left( 2.77 + 2.72 \exp\left(\frac{a}{W}\right) - 0.986 \exp\left(\frac{Lc}{L}\right) \right)$                                             |           3          | 0.995 |
| $\displaystyle \hat{K}_{II}^{\Omega} = 0$                                                                                                                                            |           -          |   -   |
| $\displaystyle \hat{K}_{III}^{\Omega} = 0$                                                                                                                                           |           -          |       |
| $\displaystyle \hat{K}_{I}^{\dot{\Omega}} = \exp \left(8.25 + 3.25 \left(\frac{a}{W}\right)^2 - 3.9 \left(\frac{L_c}{L}\right)^2 \right)$                                            |           3          | 0.996 |
| $\displaystyle \hat{K}_{II}^{\dot{\Omega}} = -5.75 -127 \left(\frac{a}{W}\right)^2 -394 \frac{a}{W} \left(1-\frac{Lc}{L}\right)$                                                     |           3          | 0.989 |
| $\displaystyle \hat{K}_{III}^{\dot{\Omega}} = 52.7 + 238 \left(\frac{a}{W}\right) \left(1-\frac{Lc}{L}\right) + 97.4 \left(\frac{a}{W}\right)^3 - 66.6 \left(\frac{L_c}{L}\right)^3$ |           4          | 0.995 |

# Conclusion {visibility="hidden"}

## Conclusion

::::{.columns}
:::{.column}

<br>

#### Summary of the methodology

1. Physics : Dimensional analysis + Superposition
    - [Isolate independent SIFs]{.muted}
    - [Find the proper dimensionless parameters]{.muted}
2. Generation of the data
    - [Sampling of the parametric space (LHS)]{.muted}
    - [Elastic simulations]{.muted}
3. Machine learning : Sparse regression
    - [Large polynomial + L1-regularization]{.muted}
    - [Injection of non-linear terms as model input]{.muted}
4. Result : Sparse analytical approximation of the SIFs
:::
:::{.column}

<br>
<br>

#### Benefits in fracture mechanics

A problem of fracture can now be [**fully analytical**]{.example} facilitating

- uncertainty quantification,
- design (parametric optimization of structure),
- stability analysis,
- etc.

:::
